dictionary.definition: [of dates] a year after the year 1 according to the Western calendar. (Offered as a replacement for Anno Domini and A.D.) _ The comet was last seen in the year 1986 in the Common Era.  The Huns invaded Gaul in 451 C.E.

[of dates] a year after the year 1 according to the Western calendar. (Offered as a replacement for Anno Domini and A.D.) _ The comet was last seen in the year 1986 in the Common Era.  The Huns invaded Gaul in 451 C.E.

in truth; when all the facts are known; when the truth becomes known. (Usually used when someone is speculating about what the final outcome will be.) _ In the final analysis, it is usually the children who suffer most in a situation like this.  In the last analysis, you simply do not want to do as you are told!

in truth; when all the facts are known; when the truth becomes known. (Usually used when someone is speculating about what the final outcome will be.) _ In the final analysis, it is usually the children who suffer most in a situation like this.  In the last analysis, you simply do not want to do as you are told!

initially; to begin with.  In the first place, you don’t have enough money to buy one. In the second place, you don’t need one.  In the first instance, I don’t have the time. In the second place, I’m not interested.

initially; to begin with.  In the first place, you don’t have enough money to buy one. In the second place, you don’t need one.  In the first instance, I don’t have the time. In the second place, I’m not interested.
having the proper state of mind for a particular situation or for doing something. I’m not in the mood to see a movie tonight.  Are you in the mood for pizza?
having the proper state of mind for a particular situation or for doing something. I’m not in the mood to see a movie tonight.  Are you in the mood for pizza?

in very good health; in very good condition, physically and emotionally. (*Typically: be ~; get [into] ~.) _He recovered completely from his surgery and has been in the pink ever since.  She was lively and active and in the pink of condition.

in very good health; in very good condition, physically and emotionally. (*Typically: be ~; get [into] ~.) _He recovered completely from his surgery and has been in the pink ever since.  She was lively and active and in the pink of condition.

dictionary.phrase: in the twinkling of an eye
dictionary.definition: very quickly. In the twinkling of an eye, the deer had disappeared into the forest. I gave Bill ten dollars and, in the twinkling of an eye, he spent it.

dictionary.phrase: in the wink of an eye
dictionary.definition: very quickly. In the twinkling of an eye, the deer had disappeared into the forest. I gave Bill ten dollars and, in the twinkling of an eye, he spent it.

dictionary.phrase: in the unlikely event of something
dictionary.definition: if something—which probably will not happen—actually happens.  In the unlikely event of my getting the job, I’ll have to buy a car to get there every day.  In the unlikely event of a fire, please walk quickly to an exit.

dictionary.phrase: in the unlikely event that something happens
dictionary.definition: if something—which probably will not happen—actually happens.  In the unlikely event of my getting the job, I’ll have to buy a car to get there every day.  In the unlikely event of a fire, please walk quickly to an exit.
to creep slowly across something.  The little green worm inched its way across the branch.  It inched itself across the leaf.
to creep slowly across something.  The little green worm inched its way across the branch.  It inched itself across the leaf.
to creep slowly on or along something.  I inched my way along the ledge and almost fell off. Sharon inched herself along the side of the bridge.
to creep slowly on or along something.  I inched my way along the ledge and almost fell off. Sharon inched herself along the side of the bridge.

dictionary.phrase: inject something into someone, something, or some creature
dictionary.definition: to give a hypodermic injection of something to someone or an animal.  The nurse injected the medicine into my arm.  He injected a very large dose into the patient.

dictionary.phrase: inject someone, something, or some creature with something
dictionary.definition: to give a hypodermic injection of something to someone or an animal.  The nurse injected the medicine into my arm.  He injected a very large dose into the patient.

1. guiltless. (*Also: as ~.) _“Hey! You can’t throw me in jail,” cried the robber. “I’m innocent as a lamb.” 2. naive; inexperienced. (*Also: as ~.) _ She’s eighteen years old, but innocent as a newborn babe.

1. guiltless. (*Also: as ~.) _“Hey! You can’t throw me in jail,” cried the robber. “I’m innocent as a lamb.” 2. naive; inexperienced. (*Also: as ~.) _ She’s eighteen years old, but innocent as a newborn babe.

dictionary.phrase: insulate someone or something against someone or something
dictionary.definition: to protect someone or something against the effect of someone or something.  Use an extra blanket to insulate the baby against the cold.  John is a bad inf luence on the children, and I’ve taken care to insulate them against him.  We insulated the children from the effects of John and his bad habits.

dictionary.phrase: insulate someone or something from someone or something
dictionary.definition: to protect someone or something against the effect of someone or something.  Use an extra blanket to insulate the baby against the cold.  John is a bad inf luence on the children, and I’ve taken care to insulate them against him.  We insulated the children from the effects of John and his bad habits.
to bid or request someone to enter a place. Don’t leave Dan out there in the rain. Invite him into the house! _ Oh, do invite in the children!
to bid or request someone to enter a place. Don’t leave Dan out there in the rain. Invite him into the house! _ Oh, do invite in the children!

1. Is what you said correct? (With rising question intonation.) _ Henry: These are the ones we need. Andrew: Is that right? They don’t look so good to me.  Fred: Tom is the one who came in late. Rachel: Is that so? It looked like Bill to me. 2. That is what you say, but I do not believe you. (No rising question intonation. Slightly rude.) _ Mary: You are making a mess of this. Alice: Is that so? And I suppose that you’re perfect? _ Bob: I found your performance to be weak in a number of places. Henry: Is that right? I suppose you could have done better?

1. Is what you said correct? (With rising question intonation.) _ Henry: These are the ones we need. Andrew: Is that right? They don’t look so good to me.  Fred: Tom is the one who came in late. Rachel: Is that so? It looked like Bill to me. 2. That is what you say, but I do not believe you. (No rising question intonation. Slightly rude.) _ Mary: You are making a mess of this. Alice: Is that so? And I suppose that you’re perfect? _ Bob: I found your performance to be weak in a number of places. Henry: Is that right? I suppose you could have done better?

Inf. I do not know the answer.; I cannot figure it out. The question has me stumped. (The stress is on me.) _Bill: When are we supposed to go over to Tom’s? Bill: Beats me.  Sally: What’s the largest river in the world? Bob: You got me beat.

Inf. I do not know the answer.; I cannot figure it out. The question has me stumped. (The stress is on me.) _Bill: When are we supposed to go over to Tom’s? Bill: Beats me.  Sally: What’s the largest river in the world? Bob: You got me beat.

Nothing can be done to help the situation.; The situation could not have been avoided.  John: The accident has blocked traffic in two directions. Jane: It can’t be helped. They have to get the people out of the cars and send them to the hospital.  Bill: My goodness, the lawn looks dead! Sue: It can’t be helped. There’s no rain and water is rationed.  John: I’m sorry I broke your figurine. Sue: It couldn’t be helped. John: I’ll replace it. Sue: That would be nice. Bill: I’m sorry I’m late. I hope it didn’t mess things up. Bob: It can’t be helped.

Nothing can be done to help the situation.; The situation could not have been avoided.  John: The accident has blocked traffic in two directions. Jane: It can’t be helped. They have to get the people out of the cars and send them to the hospital.  Bill: My goodness, the lawn looks dead! Sue: It can’t be helped. There’s no rain and water is rationed.  John: I’m sorry I broke your figurine. Sue: It couldn’t be helped. John: I’ll replace it. Sue: That would be nice. Bill: I’m sorry I’m late. I hope it didn’t mess things up. Bob: It can’t be helped.
Everything is fine.  John: How are things going? Jane: Couldn’t be better.  Bill: I hope everything is okay with your new job. Mary: Things couldn’t be better.
Everything is fine.  John: How are things going? Jane: Couldn’t be better.  Bill: I hope everything is okay with your new job. Mary: Things couldn’t be better.

It does not trouble me at all.; I have no objection. (Compare this with (It) don’t bother me none. Not very polite or cordial. See also (It) won’t bother me any. for the future tense of this expression.) _ John: Do you mind if I sit here? Jane: Doesn’t bother me any.  Sally (smoking a cigarette): Do you mind if I smoke? Bill: It doesn’t bother me any.

It does not trouble me at all.; I have no objection. (Compare this with (It) don’t bother me none. Not very polite or cordial. See also (It) won’t bother me any. for the future tense of this expression.) _ John: Do you mind if I sit here? Jane: Doesn’t bother me any.  Sally (smoking a cigarette): Do you mind if I smoke? Bill: It doesn’t bother me any.

a phrase said when one asks a question, even when the answer is known to be no. John: Can I take some of these papers home with me? Jane: No, you can’t. You know that. John: Well, it doesn’t hurt to ask.  Sue: Can I have two of these? Sally: Certainly not! Sue: Well, it never hurts to ask. Sally: Well, it just may!

John: Well, it doesn’t hurt to ask.  Sue: Can I have two of these? Sally: Certainly not! Sue: Well, it never hurts to ask. Sally: Well, it just may!
Rur. (It) doesn’t influence me.  That excuse don’t cut no ice with me.  I’m tired of you coming home drunk. Your fancy apologies don’t cut no squares.
Rur. (It) doesn’t influence me.  That excuse don’t cut no ice with me.  I’m tired of you coming home drunk. Your fancy apologies don’t cut no squares.

Things have been difficult, but I have gotten through. Bill: I’m so sorry about all your troubles. I hope things are all right now. Bob: It hasn’t been easy, but things are okay now.  John: How are you getting on after your dog died? Bill: Things haven’t been easy.

Things have been difficult, but I have gotten through. Bill: I’m so sorry about all your troubles. I hope things are all right now. Bob: It hasn’t been easy, but things are okay now.  John: How are you getting on after your dog died? Bill: Things haven’t been easy.

dictionary.phrase: It is a poor heart that never rejoices.
dictionary.definition: Prov. Even a habitually sad person cannot be sad all the time. (Sometimes used to indicate that a habitually sad person is happy about something.) _ Jill: I’ve never seen Sam smile before, but today, at his retirement party, he smiled. Jane: It is a poor heart that never rejoices.

dictionary.phrase: It is a sad heart that never rejoices.
dictionary.definition: Prov. Even a habitually sad person cannot be sad all the time. (Sometimes used to indicate that a habitually sad person is happy about something.) _ Jill: I’ve never seen Sam smile before, but today, at his retirement party, he smiled. Jane: It is a poor heart that never rejoices.

dictionary.phrase: It is all over with someone.
dictionary.definition: Euph. Someone is about to die.; Someone has just died.  I am afraid it is all over with Aunt Sarah. Her last surgery did not go well at all.  The doctor told us that it was all over for Daddy. We sat for a moment in shock.

dictionary.phrase: It is all over for someone.
dictionary.definition: Euph. Someone is about to die.; Someone has just died.  I am afraid it is all over with Aunt Sarah. Her last surgery did not go well at all.  The doctor told us that it was all over for Daddy. We sat for a moment in shock.

dictionary.phrase: It is better to give than to receive.
dictionary.definition: Prov. It is more virtuous to give things than to get them. (Biblical.) _ Susan told her children, “Instead of thinking so much about what you want for your birthday, think about what to give your brothers and sisters for their birthdays. Remember, it is better to give than to receive.” _ Our charity encourages you to share the good things you have. It is more blessed to give than to receive.

dictionary.phrase: It is more blessed to give than to receive.
dictionary.definition: Prov. It is more virtuous to give things than to get them. (Biblical.) _ Susan told her children, “Instead of thinking so much about what you want for your birthday, think about what to give your brothers and sisters for their birthdays. Remember, it is better to give than to receive.” _ Our charity encourages you to share the good things you have. It is more blessed to give than to receive.

dictionary.phrase: It is never too late to learn.
dictionary.definition: Prov. You can always learn something new.  Alan: Help me make the salad dressing. Jane: But I don’t know anything about making salad dressing. Alan: You are never too old to learn. Grandma decided to take a course in using computers. “It’s never too late to learn,” she said.

dictionary.phrase: You are never too old to learn.

Inf. I really do not care, one way or the other. (The first one is standard, the others are colloquial.) _ Bill: Mind if I sit here? Tom: Makes no difference to me.  Bill: What would you say if I ate the last piece of cake? Bob: Don’t make me no nevermind.

a polite phrase said upon departure, at the end of a conversation.  Mary (as the elevator stops): Well, this is my f loor. I’ve got to get off. John: Bye, Mary. It’s been good talking to you.  John: It’s been good talking to you, Fred. See you around. Fred: Yeah. See you.

dictionary.phrase: (It ’s) been good to talk to you.
dictionary.definition: a polite phrase said upon departure, at the end of a conversation.  Mary (as the elevator stops): Well, this is my f loor. I’ve got to get off. John: Bye, Mary. It’s been good talking to you.  John: It’s been good talking to you, Fred. See you around. Fred: Yeah. See you.

a polite phrase said upon departure, at the end of a conversation.  Mary (as the elevator stops): Well, this is my f loor. I’ve got to get off. John: Bye, Mary. It’s been good talking to you.  John: It’s been good talking to you, Fred. See you around. Fred: Yeah. See you.
I feel welcome in this place.; It is good to be here.  John: I’m so glad you could come. Jane: Thank you. It’s good to be here.  Alice: Welcome to our house! John: Thank you, it’s nice to be here.
I feel welcome in this place.; It is good to be here.  John: I’m so glad you could come. Jane: Thank you. It’s good to be here.  Alice: Welcome to our house! John: Thank you, it’s nice to be here.
Welcome to this place.; It is good that you are here.  John: It’s a pleasure to have you here. Jane: Thank you for asking me.  Alice: Oh, I’m so glad I came! Fred: Nice to have you here.
Welcome to this place.; It is good that you are here.  John: It’s a pleasure to have you here. Jane: Thank you for asking me.  Alice: Oh, I’m so glad I came! Fred: Nice to have you here.

dictionary.phrase: It’s no use crying over spilled milk.
dictionary.definition: Prov. Do not be upset about making a mistake, since you cannot change that now.  I know you don’t like your new haircut, but you can’t change it now. It’s no use crying over spilled milk.  OK, so you broke the drill I lent you. Don’t cry over spilled milk.

Prov. Do not be upset about making a mistake, since you cannot change that now.  I know you don’t like your new haircut, but you can’t change it now. It’s no use crying over spilled milk.  OK, so you broke the drill I lent you. Don’t cry over spilled milk.
It’s not done.; It’s not acceptable.  You can’t do that! It’s not cricket!
It’s not done.; It’s not acceptable.  You can’t do that! It’s not cricket!

a phrase indicating that someone or something is not meant to do something. (Often with a person’s name or a pronoun as a subject. See the examples.) _ Fred: This little piece keeps falling off. Clerk: It’s not supposed to.  Bill: Tom just called from Detroit and says he’s coming back tomorrow. Mary: That’s funny. He’s not supposed to.

Clerk: It’s not supposed to.  Bill: Tom just called from Detroit and says he’s coming back tomorrow. Mary: That’s funny. He’s not supposed to.
Rur. It is raining very hard.  Take an umbrella. It’s raining pitchforks and hammer handles out there! _ Charlie: Have you looked outside? How’s the weather? Mary: It’s raining cats and dogs.
Rur. It is raining very hard.  Take an umbrella. It’s raining pitchforks and hammer handles out there! _ Charlie: Have you looked outside? How’s the weather? Mary: It’s raining cats and dogs.

Inf. Fig. a phrase indicating that it is time that one departed. have to shove off and (It’s) time to run for other possible variations.) _Henry: Look at the clock. It’s past midnight. It’s time to hit the road. Andy: Yeah. We’ve got to go. Sue: Okay, good night. Bill: I’ve got to hit the road. I have a long day tomorrow. Mary: Okay, good night. Bill: Bye, Mary.

Inf. an announcement of one’s desire or need to depart. have to shove off and (It’s) time to hit the road for an illustration of other possible variations.) _ Andy: Time to push off. I’ve got to get home. Henry: See you, dude.  John: It’s time to split. I’ve got to go. Sue: Okay. See you tomorrow.

Inf. It will not trouble me at all.; I have no objection if you wish to do that. (Not very polite or cordial. For the present tense of this expression, see also (It) doesn’t bother me any.) _ John: Will you mind if I sit here? Jane: Won’t bother me any. Sally (lighting a cigarette): Do you mind if I smoke? Bill: It won’t bother me at all.

Inf. It will not trouble me at all.; I have no objection if you wish to do that. (Not very polite or cordial. Bill: It won’t bother me at all.

[of a hand] in need of a tip. (As if placing money in the palm would stop the itching. *Typically: get ~; have ~; give someone ~.) _ All the waiters at that restaurant have itchy palms.  The cabdriver was troubled by an itching palm. Since he refused to carry my bags, I gave him nothing.  Whenever he sees expensive luggage, the hotel doorman gets an itching palm.

The cabdriver was troubled by an itching palm. Since he refused to carry my bags, I gave him nothing.  Whenever he sees expensive luggage, the hotel doorman gets an itching palm.
very small. (Childish.) _ I remember when you was just an itty-bitty baby. Gramma sewed with itsy-bitsy stitches.
very small. (Childish.) _ I remember when you was just an itty-bitty baby. Gramma sewed with itsy-bitsy stitches.

Inf. an answer to a question about what one has been doing during very hot weather.  Jane: How do you like this hot weather? Bill: I’ve been keeping cool.  Mary: Been keeping cool? Bob: Yeah. Been keeping cool.

Inf. an answer to a question about what one has been doing during very hot weather.  Jane: How do you like this hot weather? Bill: I’ve been keeping cool.  Mary: Been keeping cool? Bob: Yeah. Been keeping cool.

a standard response to a greeting inquiry asking what one has been doing. Bill: What have you been doing? Bob: I’ve been keeping myself busy. What about you? Bill: About the same.  John: Yo! What have you been up to? Bill: Been keeping myself busy.

a standard response to a greeting inquiry asking what one has been doing. Bill: What have you been doing? Bob: I’ve been keeping myself busy. What about you? Bill: About the same.  John: Yo! What have you been up to? Bill: Been keeping myself busy.

a standard response to a greeting inquiry that asks what one has been doing.  John: What have you been doing, Fred? Fred: Been keeping out of trouble. John: Yeah. Me too. Mary: How are things, Tom? Tom: Oh, I’ve been keeping out of trouble.

a standard response to a greeting inquiry that asks what one has been doing.  John: What have you been doing, Fred? Fred: Been keeping out of trouble. John: Yeah. Me too. Mary: How are things, Tom? Tom: Oh, I’ve been keeping out of trouble.
Inf. I have to leave right now.  Time’s up. I’ve got to f ly.  I’ve gotta f ly. See you later.

a polite expression said to a host or hostess on departure.  Bob: I’ve had a lovely time. Thanks for asking me. Fred: We’re just delighted you could come. Good night. Bob: Good night. Sue: We’ve had a lovely time. Good night. Bill: Next time don’t stay away so long. Good night.

a polite expression said to a host or hostess on departure.  Bob: I’ve had a lovely time. Thanks for asking me. Fred: We’re just delighted you could come. Good night. Bob: Good night. Sue: We’ve had a lovely time. Good night. Bill: Next time don’t stay away so long. Good night.

a response to a greeting inquiry into one’s health or state of being.  Mary: How are you, Sally? Sally: Never been better, Mary. How about you? _Doctor: How are you, Jane? Jane: Never felt better. Doctor: Then why are you here?

a response to a greeting inquiry into one’s health or state of being.  Mary: How are you, Sally? Sally: Never been better, Mary. How about you? _Doctor: How are you, Jane? Jane: Never felt better. Doctor: Then why are you here?
to stab something into something.  Billy jabbed his spoon into the gelatin.  He jabbed in his spoon.  He jabbed it in.
to stab something into something.  Billy jabbed his spoon into the gelatin.  He jabbed in his spoon.  He jabbed it in.
Sl. to waste time.  Stop jacking around and get some work done! _ The kids spend most of the day jerking around.
Sl. to waste time.  Stop jacking around and get some work done! _ The kids spend most of the day jerking around.

Sl. to give someone a difficult time; to harass someone. Come on! Stop jacking me around! _ Max started jerking Lefty around, and it looked as if there was going to be trouble.  You jack around everyone you know!

dictionary.phrase: jam someone or something in((to) something)
dictionary.definition: to force or compress someone or something into something or some place. Sam jammed all his clothes into the canvas bag. The conductor jammed all the passengers into one car.  Don’t jam in everything! _ They had to jam themselves into the tiny room, because there was no other place to meet.

to force or compress someone or something into something or some place. Sam jammed all his clothes into the canvas bag. The conductor jammed all the passengers into one car.  Don’t jam in everything! _ They had to jam themselves into the tiny room, because there was no other place to meet.
to hassle someone; to waste someone’s time.  Stop jerking me around and give me my money back.  They sure like to jerk around people in that music shop.
to hassle someone; to waste someone’s time.  Stop jerking me around and give me my money back.  They sure like to jerk around people in that music shop.

dictionary.phrase: jerk someone or something out of something
dictionary.definition: to pull someone or something out of something sharply and quickly.  She jerked the baby out of the crib and ran from the burning room.  I jerked the puppy out of the mud. She jerked out the puppy before it got soaked.

to pull someone or something out of something sharply and quickly.  She jerked the baby out of the crib and ran from the burning room.  I jerked the puppy out of the mud. She jerked out the puppy before it got soaked.

dictionary.phrase: jerk something off (of) someone or something
dictionary.definition: to snatch or quickly pull something off someone or something. (Of is usually retained before pronouns.) _ Alice jerked the top off the box and poured out the contents.  She jerked off the box top.
to snatch or quickly pull something off someone or something. (Of is usually retained before pronouns.) _ Alice jerked the top off the box and poured out the contents.  She jerked off the box top.

dictionary.phrase: jerk something out of someone or something
dictionary.definition: to pull something out of someone or something quickly.  The doctor jerked the arrow out of Bill’s leg.  He jerked out the arrow.
to pull something out of someone or something quickly.  The doctor jerked the arrow out of Bill’s leg.  He jerked out the arrow.
[for a road, path, etc.] to turn to the right or left. The road jogs to the right here. Don’t run off.  Keep going until the road jogs to the left. Our driveway is on the right side.
[for a road, path, etc.] to turn to the right or left. The road jogs to the right here. Don’t run off.  Keep going until the road jogs to the left. Our driveway is on the right side.
to connect things or people. I joined Fred with the others. We joined the older puppies with the fullgrown dogs.
to connect things or people. I joined Fred with the others. We joined the older puppies with the fullgrown dogs.
to join the fight or argument.  After listening to the argument, Mary decided to jump into the fray.  Tom joined the fray and immediately got knocked down.
to join the fight or argument.  After listening to the argument, Mary decided to jump into the fray.  Tom joined the fray and immediately got knocked down.
to join the fight or argument.  After listening to the argument, Mary decided to jump into the fray.  Tom joined the fray and immediately got knocked down.
to start or stop moving suddenly, causing a jolt.  The truck jolted to a stop at the stop sign.  The little car jolted to a quick start and threw the passenger back in his seat.
to start or stop moving suddenly, causing a jolt.  The truck jolted to a stop at the stop sign.  The little car jolted to a quick start and threw the passenger back in his seat.

dictionary.phrase: Judge not, lest ye be judged.
dictionary.definition: Prov. If you condemn other people, then they will have the right to condemn you, so it is best not to condemn them. (Biblical.) _ Jill: I’m sure Gloria is the one who’s been stealing from petty cash. She’s so sloppy, nasty, and ill-mannered. Don’t you think she’d be capable of theft? Jane: Judge not, lest ye be judged.

dictionary.phrase: Judge not, that ye be not judged.
dictionary.definition: Prov. If you condemn other people, then they will have the right to condemn you, so it is best not to condemn them. (Biblical.) _ Jill: I’m sure Gloria is the one who’s been stealing from petty cash. She’s so sloppy, nasty, and ill-mannered. Don’t you think she’d be capable of theft? Jane: Judge not, lest ye be judged.
to make a decision or judgment based on something. Judging by the amount of food eaten, everyone must have been very hungry.  Judging from the mess that’s left, the party must have been a good one.
to make a decision or judgment based on something. Judging by the amount of food eaten, everyone must have been very hungry.  Judging from the mess that’s left, the party must have been a good one.

to scold someone severely. If I don’t get home on time, my parents will jump all over me. Don’t jump on me! I didn’t do it! _Please don’t jump all over John. He wasn’t the one who broke the window.  Why are you jumping down my throat? I wasn’t even in the house when it happened.

to fail to appear in court for trial and forfeit one’s bail bond.  Not only was Bob arrested for theft, he skipped bail and left town. He’s in a lot of trouble.  The judge issued a warrant for the arrest of the man who jumped bail.

to fail to appear in court for trial and forfeit one’s bail bond.  Not only was Bob arrested for theft, he skipped bail and left town. He’s in a lot of trouble.  The judge issued a warrant for the arrest of the man who jumped bail.

to do everything possible to obey or please someone; to bend over backwards (to do something). (Trained circus animals jump through hoops.) _ She expects us to jump through hoops for her.  What do you want me to do— jump through a hoop?

to do everything possible to obey or please someone; to bend over backwards (to do something). (Trained circus animals jump through hoops.) _ She expects us to jump through hoops for her.  What do you want me to do— jump through a hoop?

to judge or decide something without having all the facts; to reach unwarranted conclusions. Now don’t jump to conclusions. Wait until you hear what I have to say. Please find out all the facts so you won’t leap to conclusions.

to judge or decide something without having all the facts; to reach unwarranted conclusions. Now don’t jump to conclusions. Wait until you hear what I have to say. Please find out all the facts so you won’t leap to conclusions.

a point or place from which to begin something. The local library is a good jumping-off point for your research.  The office job in that company would be a good jumping-off place for a career in advertising.

to be enthusiastic about someone or something.  I’m not too keen on going to Denver.  Sally is fairly keen about getting a new job.  Mary isn’t keen on her new boss.

dictionary.phrase: keep a firm grip on someone or something
dictionary.definition: to hold on to someone or something tightly.  As they approached the edge, Sally kept a firm grip on little Timmy.  She kept a tight grip on him.  Keep a firm grip on my hand as we cross the street.

dictionary.phrase: keep a tight grip on someone or something
dictionary.definition: to hold on to someone or something tightly.  As they approached the edge, Sally kept a firm grip on little Timmy.  She kept a tight grip on him.  Keep a firm grip on my hand as we cross the street.
to make good on a promise; to fulfill one’s promise.  If you can’t keep your promises, you shouldn’t make them in the first place.
to make good on a promise; to fulfill one’s promise.  If you can’t keep your promises, you shouldn’t make them in the first place.

dictionary.phrase: keep a tight rein on someone or something
dictionary.definition: to watch and control someone or something diligently. (Alludes to controlling a horse by a tight grip on the reins.) _ The office manager kept a tight rein on the staff. Mary keeps a close rein on her children.

dictionary.phrase: keep a close rein on someone or something
dictionary.definition: to watch and control someone or something diligently. (Alludes to controlling a horse by a tight grip on the reins.) _ The office manager kept a tight rein on the staff. Mary keeps a close rein on her children.

to maintain behavior that is a false show; to continue with one’s facade. (The an can be replaced with the, this, that, etc.) _ How long do I have to keep this act up? I am tired of fooling people.  I am weary of keeping up my act.

dictionary.phrase: keep an ear to the ground
dictionary.definition: to devote attention to watching or listening for clues as to what is going to happen. John had his ear to the ground, hoping to find out about new ideas in computers.  His boss told him to keep his ear to the ground so that he’d be the first to know of a new idea.

dictionary.phrase: have an ear to the ground

dictionary.phrase: keep an eye on someone or something
dictionary.definition: to watch someone or something; to monitor someone or something closely.  I have my eye on the apple tree. When the apples ripen, I’ll harvest them.  Please keep an eye on the baby.  Will you please keep your eye on my house while I’m on vacation?

dictionary.phrase: have an eye on someone or something
dictionary.definition: to watch someone or something; to monitor someone or something closely.  I have my eye on the apple tree. When the apples ripen, I’ll harvest them.  Please keep an eye on the baby.  Will you please keep your eye on my house while I’m on vacation?

dictionary.phrase: keep one’s eye(s) on someone or something

dictionary.phrase: have one’s eye on someone or something

dictionary.phrase: keep an eye out (for someone or something)
dictionary.definition: to watch for the arrival or appearance of someone or something. Please try to have an eye out for the bus.  Keep an eye out for rain.  Have your eye out for a raincoat on sale.

dictionary.phrase: have an eye out (for someone or something)
dictionary.definition: to watch for the arrival or appearance of someone or something. Please try to have an eye out for the bus.  Keep an eye out for rain.  Have your eye out for a raincoat on sale.

dictionary.phrase: keep one’s eye out (for someone or something)

dictionary.phrase: keep at arm’s length from someone or something
dictionary.definition: to retain a degree of physical or social remoteness from someone or something. I try to keep at arm’s length from Larry, since our disagreement. I keep Tom at arm’s length because we don’t get along.

dictionary.phrase: keep someone or something at arm’s length
dictionary.definition: to retain a degree of physical or social remoteness from someone or something. I try to keep at arm’s length from Larry, since our disagreement. I keep Tom at arm’s length because we don’t get along.

dictionary.phrase: keep in touch (with someone or something)
dictionary.definition: to maintain communications with someone; to maintain up-to-date knowledge about someone or something.  After my neighbor moved, we still remained in touch.  I want to stay in touch with my office over the weekend.

dictionary.phrase: remain in touch (with someone or something)
dictionary.definition: to maintain communications with someone; to maintain up-to-date knowledge about someone or something.  After my neighbor moved, we still remained in touch.  I want to stay in touch with my office over the weekend.

dictionary.phrase: stay in touch (with someone or something)
dictionary.definition: to maintain communications with someone; to maintain up-to-date knowledge about someone or something.  After my neighbor moved, we still remained in touch.  I want to stay in touch with my office over the weekend.
Inf. Fig. to leave someone alone; to stop criticizing or scolding someone. Keep off of my back! Leave me alone.  Keep off my case!
Inf. Fig. to leave someone alone; to stop criticizing or scolding someone. Keep off of my back! Leave me alone.  Keep off my case!

dictionary.phrase: keep on the right side of someone
dictionary.definition: to remain in someone’s favor. (This has nothing to do with the right-hand side.) _ You had better keep on the right side of Mr. Franklin. He’s very particular.  I will keep on the good side of him.

dictionary.phrase: keep on the good side of someone
dictionary.definition: to remain in someone’s favor. (This has nothing to do with the right-hand side.) _ You had better keep on the right side of Mr. Franklin. He’s very particular.  I will keep on the good side of him.

dictionary.phrase: stay on the good side of someone
dictionary.definition: to remain in someone’s favor. (This has nothing to do with the right-hand side.) _ You had better keep on the right side of Mr. Franklin. He’s very particular.  I will keep on the good side of him.

dictionary.phrase: stay on the right side of someone
dictionary.definition: to remain in someone’s favor. (This has nothing to do with the right-hand side.) _ You had better keep on the right side of Mr. Franklin. He’s very particular.  I will keep on the good side of him.

a phrase encouraging continued efforts.  Jane: I think I’m doing better in calculus. John: Keep trying! You can get an A.  Sue: I really want that promotion, but I keep getting turned down. Bill: Don’t quit trying! You’ll get it.

a phrase encouraging continued efforts.  Jane: I think I’m doing better in calculus. John: Keep trying! You can get an A.  Sue: I really want that promotion, but I keep getting turned down. Bill: Don’t quit trying! You’ll get it.
to stay seated; to remain in one’s chair or place.  That’s all right. Keep your chair. I’ll find my own way out.  Please keep your seats until after the question-and-answer period.
to stay seated; to remain in one’s chair or place.  That’s all right. Keep your chair. I’ll find my own way out.  Please keep your seats until after the question-and-answer period.

dictionary.phrase: keep one’s eye on someone or something
dictionary.definition: to have one’s attention directed to someone or something. Please keep your eye on the children while I go to the store.  Bill kept an eye on his expenses because he was spending too much money.

dictionary.phrase: have one’s eye on someone or something
dictionary.definition: to have one’s attention directed to someone or something. Please keep your eye on the children while I go to the store.  Bill kept an eye on his expenses because he was spending too much money.

dictionary.phrase: keep one’s eyes open (for someone or something)
dictionary.definition: to remain alert and watchful for someone or something. (The entry with peeled is informal. Peel refers to moving the eyelids back. See also keep an eye out (for someone or something).) _I’m keeping my eyes open for a sale on winter coats. Please keep your eyes peeled for Mary. She’s due to arrive here any time.  Okay. I’ll keep my eyes open.

dictionary.phrase: keep one’s eyes peeled (for someone or something)
dictionary.definition: to remain alert and watchful for someone or something. (The entry with peeled is informal. Peel refers to moving the eyelids back. See also keep an eye out (for someone or something).) _I’m keeping my eyes open for a sale on winter coats. Please keep your eyes peeled for Mary. She’s due to arrive here any time.  Okay. I’ll keep my eyes open.

dictionary.phrase: keep one’s feet on the ground
dictionary.definition: to remain calm and stable.  You will do all right if you have your feet on the ground. Don’t get carried away.  Just keep your feet on the ground and you will do fine.

dictionary.phrase: have one’s feet on the ground
dictionary.definition: to remain calm and stable.  You will do all right if you have your feet on the ground. Don’t get carried away.  Just keep your feet on the ground and you will do fine.

dictionary.phrase: keep one’s fingers crossed (for someone or something)
dictionary.definition: to wish for luck for someone or something, sometimes by actually crossing one’s fingers; to hope for a good outcome for someone or something.  I hope you win the race Saturday. I’m keeping my fingers crossed for you.  I’m trying out for a play. Keep your fingers crossed!

to wish for luck for someone or something, sometimes by actually crossing one’s fingers; to hope for a good outcome for someone or something.  I hope you win the race Saturday. I’m keeping my fingers crossed for you.  I’m trying out for a play. Keep your fingers crossed!
to be patient. Wait a minute! Keep your shirt on! _Keep your pants on! I’ll be with you in a minute.
to be patient. Wait a minute! Keep your shirt on! _Keep your pants on! I’ll be with you in a minute.

to hold back an expression of anger. (The opposite of lose one’s temper.) _ She should have learned to keep her temper when she was a child.  Sally got thrown off the team because she couldn’t hold her temper.

to hold back an expression of anger. (The opposite of lose one’s temper.) _ She should have learned to keep her temper when she was a child.  Sally got thrown off the team because she couldn’t hold her temper.

dictionary.phrase: keep one step ahead of someone or something
dictionary.definition: to be or stay slightly in advance of someone or something.  Al kept one step ahead of Detective Rogers.  Try to keep one step ahead of the investigators.

dictionary.phrase: stay one step ahead of someone or something
dictionary.definition: to be or stay slightly in advance of someone or something.  Al kept one step ahead of Detective Rogers.  Try to keep one step ahead of the investigators.
Don’t get in my pathway. John: Keep out of my way! I’m carrying a heavy load. Bill: Sorry. “Keep out of my way!” shouted the piano mover.
Don’t get in my pathway. John: Keep out of my way! I’m carrying a heavy load. Bill: Sorry. “Keep out of my way!” shouted the piano mover.

This is not your business, so do not try to get involved.  John: Now you listen to me, Fred! Mary: That’s no way to talk to Fred! John: Keep out of this, Mary! Mind your own business! Fred: Stay out of this, Mary! Mary: It’s just as much my business as it is yours.

to refrain from talking about someone or something; to keep a secret about someone or something.  Please keep quiet about the missing money. Please keep still about it. All right. I’ll keep still.
to refrain from talking about someone or something; to keep a secret about someone or something.  Please keep quiet about the missing money. Please keep still about it. All right. I’ll keep still.
to restrain people from moving forward or getting in the way.  The police were ordered to keep people back so they wouldn’t interfere with the paramedics.
to restrain people from moving forward or getting in the way.  The police were ordered to keep people back so they wouldn’t interfere with the paramedics.
to have someone or something nearby habitually.  Try to keep some spare parts about.  He doesn’t work very hard, but we keep him around anyway.
to have someone or something nearby habitually.  Try to keep some spare parts about.  He doesn’t work very hard, but we keep him around anyway.

dictionary.phrase: keep someone or something in check
dictionary.definition: to keep someone or something under control; to restrain someone or something.  Hang on to this rope to keep the dog in check.  I was so angry I could hardly hold myself in check.

dictionary.phrase: hold someone or something in check
dictionary.definition: to keep someone or something under control; to restrain someone or something.  Hang on to this rope to keep the dog in check.  I was so angry I could hardly hold myself in check.

dictionary.phrase: keep someone or something in mind
dictionary.definition: to remember and think about someone or something.  When you’re driving a car, you must bear this in mind at all times: Keep your eyes on the road.  As you leave home, keep your family in mind.

dictionary.phrase: bear someone or something in mind
dictionary.definition: to remember and think about someone or something.  When you’re driving a car, you must bear this in mind at all times: Keep your eyes on the road.  As you leave home, keep your family in mind.
to keep something a secret.  I’m quitting my job, but my boss doesn’t know yet. Please keep it quiet. Okay. I’ll keep it still.
to keep something a secret.  I’m quitting my job, but my boss doesn’t know yet. Please keep it quiet. Okay. I’ll keep it still.

to monitor someone or something; to follow the activities of someone or something.  I’m supposed to keep track of my books.  Try to keep tabs on everyone who works for you. It’s hard to keep tabs when you have a lot of other work to do. I can’t keep track of the money I earn. Maybe someone else is spending it.

Rur. to have lots of children. Sally’s pregnant again, with their sixth. They sure do keep the stork f lying! _ Grandma and grandpa kept the stork f lying. I’ve got ten aunts and uncles.

to maintain a false front; to act in a special way that is different from one’s natural behavior.  Most of the time John kept up an act. He was really not a friendly person. He works hard to keep up his act.

Inf. Just wait a minute! _ I’ll be right with you. Keep your shirt on! _ Keep your pants on! You’re next.

to be excited or anxious. (*Typically: be ~; get ~.) _ Why are you so keyed up about nothing? _ She is keyed up over her son’s health.
to be excited or anxious. (*Typically: be ~; get ~.) _ Why are you so keyed up about nothing? _ She is keyed up over her son’s health.
to break a habit. It’s hard to kick a habit, but it can be done. I stopped biting my nails.  I used to drink coffee every morning, but I kicked the habit.

Sl. to actively motivate people to do something.  It looks like I’m going to have to kick ass to get people moving around here.

dictionary.phrase: a kick in the (seat of the) pants
dictionary.definition: Inf. a strong message of encouragement or demand. (Use ass and butt with discretion.) _ All he needs is a kick in the seat of the pants to get him going.  A kick in the butt will get her moving.
Inf. a strong message of encouragement or demand. (Use ass and butt with discretion.) _ All he needs is a kick in the seat of the pants to get him going.  A kick in the butt will get her moving.

to kick very hard. They say that ostriches will kick like a mule if you bother them. Stay away from the back end of Tom’s horse. It will kick like a steer when a stranger comes up.
to kick very hard. They say that ostriches will kick like a mule if you bother them. Stay away from the back end of Tom’s horse. It will kick like a steer when a stranger comes up.

dictionary.phrase: kick something off (of) someone or something
dictionary.definition: to knock something off someone or something by kicking. (Of is usually retained before pronouns.) _ The baby must have kicked her covers off of herself in the night.  She kicked off her covers in the night.

to knock something off someone or something by kicking. (Of is usually retained before pronouns.) _ The baby must have kicked her covers off of herself in the night.  She kicked off her covers in the night.
to move something out of something or some place by kicking.  The soccer player kicked the ball out of the tangle of legs. She got into the fracas and kicked out the ball.
to move something out of something or some place by kicking.  The soccer player kicked the ball out of the tangle of legs. She got into the fracas and kicked out the ball.

dictionary.phrase: kick the (natural) stuffing out of someone
dictionary.definition: Rur. to kick or beat someone severely. Last time I was in a fight with Joe, he kicked the natural stuffing out of me. You do that again and I’ll kick the stuffing out of you. Bill threatened to beat the natural stuffing out of any no-’count rascal who laid a hand on his sister.

to become a nuisance; to misbehave and disturb (someone). (Row rhymes with cow. Note the variations in the examples.) _The customer kicked up such a fuss about the food that the manager came to apologize.  I kicked up such a row that they told me to leave. Oh, what pain! My arthritis is kicking up a storm.

Prov. Those who are in power can always catch and punish people who have opposed them, no matter how far away those opponents may go. After his attempt to assassinate the king, the prince sailed to a distant country, although his wife warned him it would be to no avail. “Kings have long arms,” she reminded him.

After his attempt to assassinate the king, the prince sailed to a distant country, although his wife warned him it would be to no avail. “Kings have long arms,” she reminded him.

Rur. very small or short. (Usually used to describe children. *Typically: be ~; since someone was ~.) _ I’ve known you since you were knee-high to a jackrabbit.  My, how you’ve grown! The last time I saw you, you were knee-high to a grasshopper!

to have expected in advance that something was to happen.  I shouldn’t act surprised. I knew it was coming.  It’s his own fault. He should have known it was coming.
to have expected in advance that something was to happen.  I shouldn’t act surprised. I knew it was coming.  It’s his own fault. He should have known it was coming.
to hang around some place with someone; to wander idly about some place with someone.  Sally was knocking about France with her friends.  I knocked around town with Ken for a while.

Sl. to swallow a drink of an alcoholic beverage.  Todd knocked back one drink, and then had another.  Kelly knocked one back. She knocked one over and left the bar.

to strike one, making one smarter, or at least obedient.  I think his father finally knocked some sense into him.  The accident finally knocked in some sense.  I thought that last week’s experience would knock some sense in.
